edge: Interstellar is a 2014 epic science fiction drama film directed by Sir Christopher Nolan.
Sir Christopher Nolan, who co-wrote the screenplay with his brother Jonathan, directed Interstellar.
The screenplay had its origins in a script Jonathan developed in 2007 and was originally set to be directed by Steven Spielberg.
The screenplay had its origins in a script Jonathan developed in 2007 and was originally set to be directed by Steven Spielberg.

Set in a dystopian future where Earth is suffering from catastrophic blight and famine, the film follows a group of astronauts who travel through a wormhole near Saturn in search of a new home for mankind.
The film stars Matthew McConaughey, Anne Hathaway, Jessica Chastain, Bill Irwin, Ellen Burstyn, Matt Damon, and Michael Caine.

After transiting a newly-formed wormhole near Saturn, the crew arrive at a planetary system, circling a supermassive black hole named Gargantua. They descend into the gravity well of Gargantua to survey the first candidate planet and return to their spacecraft, Endurance, but have lost 23 Earth-years due to the severe time dilation caused by escaping the gravity well.

The Endurance travels to the second candidate planet, a frigid ice world near Gargantua. They chart a gravity-assist path around Gargantua to reach the final candidate planet.

Mann falsifies data to attract rescuers, attacks the crew of Endurance, kills Romilly, and ultimately sacrifices himself when he fails to dock.

Warner Bros. sought a stake in Nolan's production of Interstellar from Paramount, despite their traditional rivalry.
Warner Bros. agreed to give Paramount its rights to co-finance the next film in the Friday the 13th horror franchise, with a stake in a future film based on the television series South Park.
In August 2013, Legendary Pictures finalized an agreement with Warner Bros. To finance approximately 25% of the film's production.

More IMAX cameras were used for Interstellar than for any of Nolan's previous films.
To minimize the use of computer-generated imagery (CGI), Nolan had practical locations built, such as the interior of a space shuttle.
Van Hoytema retooled an IMAX camera to be hand-held for shooting interior scenes.
Some of the film's sequences were shot with an IMAX camera installed in the nose cone of a Learjet.
The film was produced under the name Flora's Letter as a security measure.

Shooting also took place in Iceland, where Nolan had previously filmed scenes for Batman Begins (2005). It was chosen to represent two extraterrestrial planets: one covered in ice, and the other in water.
Locations included the Svínafellsjökull glacier and the town of Klaustur.
Filming locations included the Westin Bonaventure Hotel and Suites, the Los Angeles Convention Center, a Sony Pictures soundstage in Culver City, and a private residence in Altadena, California.
While filming a water scene in Iceland, Hathaway almost suffered from hypothermia because her dry suit had not been properly secured.

The Endurance, the crew's mother ship in Interstellar, is based on the International Space Station. Production designer Nathan Crowley said the Endurance was based on the International Space Station: 'It's a real mish-mash of different kinds of technology. You need analogue stuff, as well as digital stuff, you need backup systems and tangible switches. It's really like a submarine in space. Every inch of space is used, everything has a purpose.'
In Interstellar, the Endurance features a related spacecraft called the Ranger, which serves a similar function to the Space Shuttle's, being able to enter and exit planetary atmospheres.

The Endurance in Interstellar also has related spacecraft called Landers, which transport the capsules with settling equipment to planetary surfaces. Production designer Nathan Crowley compared it to 'a heavy Russian helicopter.'

In the film, two robots named CASE and TARS are featured. Nolan intentionally avoided making them anthropomorphic and instead chose a quadrilateral design based on mathematics with four main blocks that can be joined in three ways. Bill Irwin voiced and physically controlled both robots, but Josh Stewart replaced his voicing for CASE.
The human space habitats in the film resemble O'Neill cylinders, which is a theoretical space habitat model proposed by physicist Gerard K. O'Neill in 1976.
The film also features a dismantled third robot named KIPP.

Grinspoon criticized the dire 'blight' situation on Earth portrayed in the early scenes, pointing out that even with a voracious blight it would have taken millions of years to reduce the atmosphere's oxygen content.
Tyson explored the science behind the ending of Interstellar, concluding that it is theoretically possible to interact with the past.
Theoretical physicist Michio Kaku praised Interstellar for its scientific accuracy and said it 'could set the gold standard for science fiction movies for years to come.'

node_2: accounting of black holes and wormholes
edge: Former NASA software engineer Timothy Reyes said 'Thorne's and Nolan's accounting of black holes and wormholes and the use of gravity is excellent.'

Nolan was initially concerned that a scientifically accurate depiction of a black hole would not be visually comprehensible to an audience, and would require the effects team to unrealistically alter its appearance.

The visual representation of the black hole in the film does not account for the Doppler effect which, when added by the visual effects team, resulted in an asymmetrically lit black and blue-black hole.
The asymmetric brightness of the accretion disk is very well visible in the first image[70] of the event horizon of a black hole obtained by the Event Horizon Telescope team in 2019.
Futura-Sciences praised the correct depiction of the Penrose process.[71]
The portrayal of what a wormhole would look like is scientifically correct. Rather than a two-dimensional hole in space, it is depicted as a sphere, showing a distorted view of the target galaxy.[72]

Paramount Pictures launched an interactive website on which users uncovered a star chart related to the Apollo 11 Moon landing, hosted on a Google domain.
The Interstellar website featured a mobile app in October 2014 as part of Paramount's partnership with Google.

In October 2014, Google used Interstellar as a basis for promoting math and science lesson plans in schools as part of the Google for Education initiative.

Rotten Tomatoes, in their review aggregation service, reports that 73% of the 378 critic reviews for 'Interstellar' are positive and the film has been given an average rating of 7.1/10. This high percentage and rating indicate that 'Interstellar' is a thrilling movie according to the critical community.

node_2: science and faith and science and the humanities
edge: New York Times columnist David Brooks concludes that Interstellar explores the relationships among 'science and faith and science and the humanities'.
Mark Steyn commented on the technological future and the focus on the father-daughter relationship.

Wai Chee Dimock, in the Los Angeles Review of Books, wrote that Nolan's films are 'rotatable at 90, 180, and 360 degrees,' and that 'although there is considerable magical thinking here, making it almost an anti-sci-fi film, holding out hope that the end of the planet is not the end of everything, it reverses itself, however, when that magic falls short when the poetic license is naked and plain for all to see'.

node_2: most ambitious and challenging science fiction film since kubrick's 2001.
edge: Author George R. R. Martin called Interstellar 'the most ambitious and challenging science fiction film since Kubrick's 2001.'
Interstellar received nominations for Best Original Score, Best Production Design, Best Sound Editing, and 'Best Visual Effects,' and won Best Visual Effects at the 87th Academy Awards.
